info.title: Dynatrace Environment API
info.description:
Documentation of the Dynatrace Environment API v1. Refer to the [help page](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/section-api) to read about use-cases and examples.

Notes about compatibility:
* Operations marked as early adopter or preview may be changed in non-compatible ways, although we try to avoid this.
* We may add new enum constants without incrementing the API version; thus, clients need to handle unknown enum constants gracefully.

get.summary: Gets the latest available version of the OneAgent installer of the specified type
get.description:
Returns the OneAgent version of the installer of the specified type. 

Non-required parameters are only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

parameters.name: osType
parameters.description: The operating system of the installer.

parameters.name: installerType
parameters.description:
The type of the installer: 

* `default`: Self-extracting installer for manual installation. Downloads an `.exe` file for Windows or an `.sh` file for Unix. 
* `default-unattended`: Self-extracting installer for unattended installation. Windows only. Downloads a `.zip` archive, containing the `.msi` installer and the batch file. This option is deprecated with OneAgent version 1.173 
* `paas`: Code modules installer. Downloads a `*.zip` archive, containing the `manifest.json` file with meta information or a `.jar` file for z/OS. 
* `paas-sh`: Code modules installer. Downloads a self-extracting shell script with the embedded `tar.gz` archive.

parameters.name: flavor
parameters.description:
The flavor of your Linux distribution. 

 Set `musl` for Linux distributions, which are using the musl C standard library, for example Alpine Linux. 

 Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

parameters.name: arch
parameters.description:
The architecture of your OS: 

* `all`: Use this value for AIX and z/OS. Defaults to `x86` for other OS types. 
* `x86`: x86 architecture.
* `ppc`: PowerPC architecture, only supported for AIX and Linux.
* `ppcle`: PowerPC Little Endian architecture, only supported for Linux.
* `sparc`: Sparc architecture, only supported for Solaris. 

* `arm`: ARM architecture, only supported for Linux. 

* `s390`: S/390 architecture, only supported for Linux. 

Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

parameters.name: bitness
parameters.description:
The bitness of your OS. Must be supported by the OS. 

 Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

x-token-scopes: `InstallerDownload` (PaaS integration - Installer download)

parameters.name: If-None-Match
parameters.description: The ETag of the previous request. Do not download if it matches the ETag of the installer.

parameters.name: osType
parameters.description: The operating system of the installer.

parameters.name: installerType
parameters.description:

* `default`: Self-extracting installer for manual installation. Downloads an `.exe` file for Windows or an `.sh` file for Unix. 
* `default-unattended`: Self-extracting installer for unattended installation. Windows only. Downloads a `.zip` archive, containing the `.msi` installer and the batch file. This option is deprecated with OneAgent version 1.173 
* `paas`: Code modules installer. Downloads a `*.zip` archive, containing the `manifest.json` file with meta information or a `.jar` file for z/OS. 
* `paas-sh`: Code modules installer. Downloads a self-extracting shell script with the embedded `tar.gz` archive.

parameters.name: flavor
parameters.description:
The flavor of your Linux distribution. 

 Set `musl` for Linux distributions, which are using the musl C standard library, for example Alpine Linux. 

 Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

parameters.name: arch
parameters.description:
The architecture of your OS: 

* `all`: Use this value for AIX and z/OS. Defaults to `x86` for other OS types. 
* `x86`: x86 architecture.
* `ppc`: PowerPC architecture, only supported for AIX and Linux.
* `ppcle`: PowerPC Little Endian architecture, only supported for Linux.
* `sparc`: Sparc architecture, only supported for Solaris. 

* `arm`: ARM architecture, only supported for Linux. 

* `s390`: S/390 architecture, only supported for Linux. 

Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

parameters.name: bitness
parameters.description:
The bitness of your OS. Must be supported by the OS. 

 Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

parameters.name: include
parameters.description:
The code modules to be included to the installer. You can specify several modules in the following format: `include=java&include=dotnet`. 

Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

parameters.name: skipMetadata
parameters.description:
Set `true` to omit the OneAgent connectivity information from the installer. 

 Only applicable to the `paas` and `paas-sh` installer types.

200.description: Success. The payload contains the installer file.

304.description: Not modified. You already have the latest version of the installer. The response does not contain a payload.

x-token-scopes: `InstallerDownload` (PaaS integration - Installer download)

put.description:
The job anonymizes all user sessions in the specified timeframe by masking the specified fields. 

To identify user sessions to be anonymized you can specify either userID, or IP address, or both. If you specify both the **OR** logic applies. 

You can't undo the anonymization.

parameters.name: startTimestamp
parameters.description:
The start timestamp of the user session to anonymize, in UTC milliseconds.

 If not set the earliest available time is used.

parameters.name: endTimestamp
parameters.description:
The end timestamp of the user session to anonymize, in UTC milliseconds.

 If not set the current time is used.

parameters.name: userIds
parameters.description:
The UserID of the user to anonymize. 

 You can specify several IDs, in the following format: `userIds=user1&userIds=user2`.

parameters.name: ips
parameters.description:
The IP address of the user to anonymize. All user sessions from this IP will be anonymized. 

You can specify several IPs, in the following format: `ips=ip1&ips=ip2`.

parameters.name: additionalField
parameters.description:
A list of fields to be anonymized. 

You can specify several fields, in the following format: `additionalField=field1&additionalField=field2`.

200.description: Success. The response body contains the ID of the anonymization job. You can use the ID to check the job status.

400.description: Failed. The input is invalid. See the response body for details.

x-token-scopes: `UserSessionAnonymization` (Anonymize user session data for data privacy reasons)

get.summary: Shows the progress of the specified anonymization job

parameters.name: requestId
parameters.description: The ID of the required anonymization job.

200.description: Success. The response body contains the status of the anonymization job.

400.description: Failed. The input is invalid. See the response body for details.

x-token-scopes: `UserSessionAnonymization` (Anonymize user session data for data privacy reasons)

get.summary: Returns the result of the query as a table structure
get.description: The result is a flat list of rows containing the requested columns.

parameters.name: query
parameters.description:
The user session query to be executed. See the [USQL help page](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/usql-info) for syntax details. 

 You can find the available columns of the **usersession** table in the `UserSession` object. 

 Here is an example of the query: `SELECT country, city, COUNT(*) FROM usersession GROUP BY country, city`.

parameters.name: startTimestamp
parameters.description:
The start timestamp of the query, in UTC milliseconds. 

If not set or set as `0`, 2 hours behind the current time is used.

 If the exact times are important, set the timeframe in the query itself (**query** parameter).

parameters.name: endTimestamp
parameters.description:
The end timestamp of the query, in UTC milliseconds. 

If not set or set as `0`, the current timestamp is used.

 If the exact times are important, set the timeframe in the query itself (**query** parameter).

parameters.name: offsetUTC
parameters.description:
Optional offset of local time to UTC time in minutes. Offset will be applied to Date fields encountered in the query. 

Can be positive or negative. E.g. if the local time is UTC+02:00, the timeOffset is 120. If it is UTC-05:00, timeOffset is -300.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description: Optional limit on how many of the actual query results should be returned in the tabular result.

parameters.name: pageOffset
parameters.description:
Optional offset of the requested results from the start of tabular results. Relates to pageSize. 

E.g. on a query that might return 500 results, you might want to receive results in chunks of 50 rows. 

this can be achieved by using pageSize=50, and setting pageOffset in subsequent calls.In the example adding pageOffset=50 returns result rows 51-100.

parameters.name: addDeepLinkFields
parameters.description:
Add (`true`) to enable deep linking of additional fields in the query. 

If not set, then `false` is used

parameters.name: explain
parameters.description:
Add (`true`) or don't add (`false`) some additional information about the result to the response. 

It helps to understand the query and how the result was calculated. 

If not set, then `false` is used

200.description: Success. The response contains the result of the query.

404.description: Failed. The query is invalid. See the response body for more information.

999.description: The data structure of the user session. This response code is never returned.

x-token-scopes: `DTAQLAccess` (User sessions)

get.summary: Gets the parameters of the specified event

parameters.name: eventId
parameters.description: The ID of the required event.

x-token-scopes: `DataExport` (Access problem and event feed, metrics, and topology)

get.summary: Lists all the events of your environment, along with their parameters
get.description:
Because the possible number of events can be huge, the response is limited to 150 events. You can focus the output by specifying filtering parameters for the request.

An event is included in the response, if either start or end timestamp of the event is within the defined timeframe.

parameters.name: from
parameters.description:
Start timestamp of the query, in UTC milliseconds. 

 If not set, 30 days ago from now is used, unless **relativeTime** is set.

parameters.name: to
parameters.description:
End timestamp of the query, in UTC milliseconds. 

 If not set, the current timestamp is used, unless **relativeTime** is set. 

The timeframe must not exceed 2 years.

parameters.name: relativeTime
parameters.description: Relative timeframe, back from the current time.

parameters.name: eventType
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of events by the event type.

parameters.name: entityId
parameters.description: Filters the resulting set of events to the events, related to the specified Dynatrace entity.

parameters.name: cursor
parameters.description:
The response is limited to 150 events, so if you want to receive more you can use the cursor to get the next 150. This parameter should be empty when querying for the first time.  

The cursor key can then be found in the **nextCursor** field of the previous response. 

When using the cursor string, it is not necessary to specify the additional parameters, as that info is already encoded within the cursor.

x-token-scopes: `DataExport` (Access problem and event feed, metrics, and topology)

post.summary: Pushes custom events to one or more monitored entities
post.description:
You can use this endpoint to: 

* Push information-only events from third-party systems such as CI platforms (Jenkins, Bamboo, Electric Cloud, etc.) to provide additional information for Dynatrace automated root cause analysis. The time of event closure is already known and the event IDs are returned instantly. You can report these events for up to **30 days** into the past. The information-only event types are: 
`CUSTOM_ANNOTATION` 
 `CUSTOM_CONFIGURATION` 
 `CUSTOM_DEPLOYMENT` 
 `CUSTOM_INFO` 
 `MARKED_FOR_TERMINATION` 

* Push problem-opening events (for example, an error rate increase) to trigger the Dynatrace automated root cause analysis engine.  Correlation IDs are returned instead of event IDs. These events stay open until the specified timeout expires. To prevent expiration, you can refresh these events by sending the same payload again. You can report these events for up to **60 minutes** into the past. The problem-opening event types are (sorted by severity level, descending): 
`AVAILABILITY_EVENT` 
 `ERROR_EVENT` 
 `PERFORMANCE_EVENT` 
 `RESOURCE_CONTENTION` 

The actual set of event parameters depends on the type of your event. See the [documentation](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/api-events-post-event) for the properties mapping.

requestBody.description: The JSON body of the request, containing parameters of the event.

x-token-scopes: `DataExport` (Access problem and event feed, metrics, and topology)

get.summary: Lists all monitored processes along with their parameters
get.description:
You can narrow down the output by specifying filtering parameters for the request. 

You can additionally limit the output by using pagination: 
1. Specify the number of results per page in the **pageSize** query parameter. 
2. Then use the URL-encoded cursor from the **Next-Page-Key** response header in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages.

parameters.name: startTimestamp
parameters.description:
The start timestamp of the requested timeframe, in milliseconds (UTC). 

If not set, then 72 hours behind from now is used.

parameters.name: endTimestamp
parameters.description:
The end timestamp of the requested timeframe, in milliseconds (UTC). 

If not set, then the current timestamp is used. 

The timeframe must not exceed 3 days.

parameters.name: relativeTime
parameters.description: The relative timeframe, back from now.

parameters.name: tag
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of processes by the specified tag. You can specify several tags in the following format: `tag=tag1&tag=tag2`. The process has to match **all** the specified tags. 

In case of key-value tags, such as imported AWS or CloudFoundry tags, use the following format: `tag=[context]key:value`. For custom key-value tags, omit the context: `tag=key:value`.

parameters.name: entity
parameters.description:
Filters result to the specified processes only. 

 To specify several processes use the following format: `entity=ID1&entity=ID2`.

parameters.name: hostTag
parameters.description:
Filters processes by the host they're running at. 

 Specify tags of the host you're interested in.

parameters.name: host
parameters.description:
Filters processes by the host they're running at. 

 Specify Dynatrace IDs of the host you're interested in. 

 To specify several hosts use the following format: `host=hostID1&host=hostID2`. 

 The **OR** logic applies.

parameters.name: actualMonitoringState
parameters.description: Filters processes by the actual monitoring state of the process.

parameters.name: expectedMonitoringState
parameters.description: Filters processes by the expected monitoring state of the process.

parameters.name: managementZone
parameters.description: Only return processes that are part of the specified management zone.

parameters.name: includeDetails
parameters.description:
Includes (`true`) or excludes (`false`) details which are queried from related entities.

Excluding details may make queries faster. 

If not set, then `true` is used.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description:
The number of processes per result page. 

 If not set, pagination is not used and the result contains all processes fitting the specified filtering criteria.

parameters.name: nextPageKey
parameters.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. You can find it in the **Next-Page-Key** header of the previous response. 

If you're using pagination, the first page is always returned without this cursor. 

You must keep all other query parameters as they were in the first request to obtain subsequent pages.

Next-Page-Key.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. Without it you'll get the first page again.

 The cursor must be URL-encoded.

Page-Size.description: The maximum number of results per page.

get.summary: Gets the list of all applications in your environment along with their parameters

You can narrow down the output by specifying filtering parameters for the request. 

You can additionally limit the output by using pagination: 
1. Specify the number of results per page in the **pageSize** query parameter.

parameters.name: startTimestamp

parameters.name: endTimestamp

The timeframe must not exceed 3 days.

The special characters must be escaped.

get.summary: Lists all available hosts in your environment
get.description:
You can narrow down the output by specifying filtering parameters for the request. 

You can additionally limit the output by using pagination: 
1. Specify the number of results per page in the **pageSize** query parameter. 
2. Then use the URL-encoded cursor from the **Next-Page-Key** response header in the **nextPageKey** query parameter to obtain subsequent pages.

parameters.name: startTimestamp
parameters.description:
The start timestamp of the requested timeframe, in milliseconds (UTC). 

If not set, then 72 hours behind from now is used.

parameters.name: endTimestamp
parameters.description:
The end timestamp of the requested timeframe, in milliseconds (UTC). 

If not set, then the current timestamp is used. 

The timeframe must not exceed 3 days.

parameters.name: relativeTime
parameters.description: The relative timeframe, back from now.

parameters.name: tag
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of hosts by the specified tag. You can specify several tags in the following format: `tag=tag1&tag=tag2`. The host has to match **all** the specified tags. 

In case of key-value tags, such as imported AWS or CloudFoundry tags, use the following format: `tag=[context]key:value`. For custom key-value tags, omit the context: `tag=key:value`.

parameters.name: showMonitoringCandidates
parameters.description:
Includes (`true`) or excludes (`false`) a monitoring candidate in the response. 

Monitoring candidates are network entities that are detected but not monitored.

parameters.name: entity
parameters.description:
Filters result to the specified hosts only. 

 To specify several hosts use the following format: `entity=ID1&entity=ID2`.

parameters.name: managementZone
parameters.description: Only return hosts that are part of the specified management zone.

parameters.name: hostGroupId
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of hosts by the specified host group. 

 Specify the Dynatrace IDs of the host group you're interested in.

parameters.name: hostGroupName
parameters.description:
Filters the resulting set of hosts by the specified host group. 

 Specify the name of the host group you're interested in.

parameters.name: includeDetails
parameters.description:
Includes (`true`) or excludes (`false`) details which are queried from related entities.

Excluding details may make queries faster. 

If not set, then `true` is used.

parameters.name: pageSize
parameters.description:
The number of hosts per result page. 

 If not set, pagination is not used and the result contains all hosts fitting the specified filtering criteria.

parameters.name: nextPageKey
parameters.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. You can find it in the **Next-Page-Key** header of the previous response. 

If you're using pagination, the first page is always returned without this cursor. 

You must keep all other query parameters as they were in the first request to obtain subsequent pages.

Next-Page-Key.description:
The cursor for the next page of results. Without it you'll get the first page again.

 The cursor must be URL-encoded.

Page-Size.description: The maximum number of results per page.

get.summary: Gets the parameters of the specified metric and, optionally, its data points
get.description:
To obtain data points, set **includeData** to `true`. 

You can obtain either data points or the scalar result of the specified timeseries, depending on the **queryMode**. 

To obtain data points, you must specify the timeframe, either as **relativeTime** or as a combination of **startTimestamp** and **endTimestamp**. 

You must also provide the **aggregationType**, supported by the metric.

parameters.name: timeseriesIdentifier
parameters.description: The case-sensitive ID of the timeseries, from which you want to read parameters and data points.

parameters.name: includeData
parameters.description:
The flag to include data points in the response. Set to `true` to obtain data points. You must also specify the timeframe and aggregation type. 

Defaults to `false`, meaning data points are not included.

parameters.name: aggregationType
parameters.description:
The aggregation type for the resulting data points. 

If the requested metric doesn't support the specified aggregation, the request will result in an error.

parameters.name: startTimestamp
parameters.description: The start timestamp of the requested timeframe, in UTC milliseconds.

parameters.name: endTimestamp
parameters.description:
The end timestamp of the requested timeframe, in milliseconds (UTC). 

If later than the current time, Dynatrace automatically uses the current time instead. 

The timeframe must not exceed 6 months.

parameters.name: predict
parameters.description: The flag to predict future data points.

parameters.name: relativeTime
parameters.description: The relative timeframe, back from the current time.

parameters.name: queryMode
parameters.description:
The type of result that the call should return. Valid result modes are: 

`series`: returns all the data points of the timeseries in specified timeframe. 
`total`: returns one scalar value for the specified timeframe. 

By default, the `series` mode is used.

parameters.name: entity
parameters.description:
Filters requested data points by the entity that should deliver them. Allowed values are Dynatrace entity IDs. 

You can specify several entities in the following format: `entity=entity1&entity=entity2`. The entity has to match at least one of the specified IDs. 

If the selected entity doesn't support the requested timeseries, the request will result in an error.

parameters.name: tag
parameters.description:
Filters requested data points by entity which should deliver them. Only data from entities with the specified tag is delivered. 

You can specify several tags in the following format: `tag=tag1&tag=tag2`. The entity has to match **all** the specified tags. 

In case of key-value tags, such as imported AWS or CloudFoundry tags use the `key:value` format. If there's also a context, use the `[context]key:value` format.

parameters.name: percentile
parameters.description:
Specifies which percentile of the selected response time metric should be delivered.

Applicable only to the `PERCENTILE` aggregation type. 

Valid values for percentile are between 1 and 99. 

Keep in mind that percentile export is possible only for response-time-based metrics such as application and service response times.

parameters.name: includeParentIds
parameters.description:
If set to true the result exposes dimension mappings between parent entities and their children.

For instance: SERVICE-0000000000000001, SERVICE_METHOD-0000000000000001

parameters.name: considerMaintenanceWindowsForAvailability
parameters.description: Exclude (`true`) or include (`false`) data points from any [maintenance window](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/maintenance-window), defined in your environment.

x-token-scopes: `DataExport` (Access problem and event feed, metrics, and topology)

You can use alphanumeric characters and the following punctuation marks: periods (`.`), hyphens (`-`), and commas (`,`). A number cannot follow a punctuation mark. 

If you use the ID of an existing metric the respective parameters will be updated.

version.description: The version of the Dynatrace server.

tenantUUID.description: The ID of your Dynatrace environment.

tenantToken.description: The internal token that is used for authentication when OneAgent connects to the Dynatrace cluster to send data.

communicationEndpoints.description: The list of endpoints to connect to the Dynatrace environment. The list is sorted by endpoint priority, descending.

sha256.description:
The checksum of the  BOSH release tarball. 

 This is the sha256 hash of the installer file.

BoshReleaseChecksum.description: The checksum of the BOSH release tarball.

availableVersions.description: A list of available OneAgent versions for BOSH release tarballs.

BoshReleaseAvailableVersions.description: A list of available OneAgent versions for BOSH release tarballs.

availableVersions.description: A list of available versions of OneAgent installer.

AgentInstallerVersions.description: A list of available versions of OneAgent installer.

ActiveGateInstallerVersions.description: A list of available versions of ActiveGate installer.

requestId.description: The ID of the newly created anonymization job.

progress.description:
The progress of the anonymization job, percent. 

-1 if the job is waiting for execution.

extrapolationLevel.description:
The extrapolation level of the result. 

To improve performance, some results may be calculated from a subset of actual data. The extrapolation level indicates the share of actual data in the result. 

The number is the denominator of a fraction and indicates the amount of actual data. The value `1` means that the result contains only the actual data. The value `4` means that result is calculated using 1/4 of the actual data. 

If you need the analysis to be based on the actual data, reduce the timeframe of your query. For example, in case of extrapolation level of `4`, try to use 1/4 of the original timeframe.

additionalColumnNames.description:
A list of columns in the additionalValues table. 

 Only present if the endpoint was called with `deepLinkFields=true` parameter.

additionalValues.description:
A list of data rows. 

 Each array element represents a row in the table of additionally linked fields. 

The size of each data row and the order of the elements correspond to the **additionalColumnNames** content.

 Only present if the endpoint was called with `deepLinkFields=true` parameter.

explanations.description:
Additional information about the query and the result, that helps to understand the query and how the result was calculated. 

Only appears when the **explain** parameter is set to `true`. 

Example: The number of results was limited to the default of 50. Use the `LIMIT` clause to increase or decrease this limit.

columnNames.description: A list of columns in the result table.

values.description:
A list of data rows. 

 Each array element represents a row in the result table. 

The size of each data row and the order of the elements correspond to the **columnNames** content.

DtaqlResultAsTable.description: The user session query result as a table.

key.description: The custom key of the property.

value.description: The date value of the property.

DateProperty.description: A custom property of the user-action with a date value.

key.description: The custom key of the property.

value.description: The floating-point numeric value of the property.

DoubleProperty.description: A custom property of the user action with a Double value.

key.description: The custom key of the property.

value.description: The Long value of the property.

LongProperty.description: A custom property of the user action with a Long value.

key.description: The custom key of the property.

value.description: The string value of the property.

StringProperty.description: A custom property of the user action with a string value.

tenantId.description:
The ID of the Dynatrace environment that captured the user session. 

This field can not be queried via the User Session Query Language.

userSessionId.description: The unique ID of the user session.

startTime.description: The timestamp of the first user action in the user session, in UTC milliseconds.

endTime.description: The timestamp of the last user action in the user session, in UTC milliseconds.

duration.description:
The duration of the user session, in milliseconds. 

 This is calculated as the amount of time between the start of the first user action and the end of the last user action.

internalUserId.description: The unique ID of the user that triggered the user session.

userType.description: The type of the user. Indicates either a real human user (`REAL_USER`) or a robot (`ROBOT` or `SYNTHETIC`).

applicationType.description: The type of the application used in the user session.

bounce.description:
The user session has (`true`) or doesn't have (`false`) a bounce. 

 A bounce means there is only one user action in the user session.

newUser.description: The user is a first-time (`true`) or a returning user (`false`).

userActionCount.description: The number of user actions in the user session.

totalErrorCount.description: The number of errors detected in the user session.

matchingConversionGoalsCount.description: The number of conversion goals achieved by the user session.

 This is calculated as average time it takes for all visible parts of a page to display.

domContentLoadedTime.description: The amount of time until the DOM tree is loaded, in milliseconds.

userActionPropertyCount.description: The total number of user action properties in the user action.

UserSessionUserAction.description:
A user action. 

 A user action is a single action performed by the user as part of a user session, for example a mouse click.

extrapolationLevel.description:
The extrapolation level of the result. 

To improve performance, some results may be calculated from a subset of actual data. The extrapolation level indicates the share of actual data in the result. 

The number is the denominator of a fraction and indicates the amount of actual data. The value `1` means that the result contains only the actual data. The value `4` means that result is calculated using 1/4 of the actual data. 

If you need the analysis to be based on the actual data, reduce the timeframe of your query. For example, in case of extrapolation level of `4`, try to use 1/4 of the original timeframe.

additionalColumnNames.description:
A list of columns in the additionalValues table. 

 Only present if the endpoint was called with `deepLinkFields=true` parameter.

additionalValues.description:
A list of data rows. 

 Each array element represents a row in the table of additionally linked fields. 

The size of each data row and the order of the elements correspond to the **additionalColumnNames** content.

 Only present if the endpoint was called with `deepLinkFields=true` parameter.

explanations.description:
Additional information about the query and the result, that helps to understand the query and how the result was calculated. 

Only appears when the **explain** parameter is set to `true`. 

Example: The number of results was limited to the default of 50. Use the `LIMIT` clause to increase or decrease this limit.

branchNames.description:
A list of branches of the tree. 

 Typically, these are fields from the `SELECT` clause, that have been used in the `GROUP BY` clause.

leafNames.description:
A list of leaves on each tree branch. 

 Typically, these are fields from the `SELECT` clause, that have not been used in the `GROUP BY` clause.

values.description: The user session query result as a tree.

Set of parameters of the event.

The origin of the tag, such as AWS or Cloud Foundry.

The key of the tag. 

 Custom tags have the tag value here.

The value of the tag.

nextEventId.description: ID of the next event if the total number of events exceeds the maximum batch size of 150 events per request.

nextCursor.description:
The cursor for the next 150 events, fitting the specified criteria. 

 Set this value for the **cursor** query parameter. Without it you'll get the first 150 events again. 

You don't have to specify any additional parameters, because the cursor already contains all of them.

totalEventCount.description: The total amount of events, fitting the specified criteria.

storedEventIds.description:
List of event IDs for information-only-events. 

 This field is provided for compatibility reasons. You should use the values from the **storedIds** field instead.

storedIds.description: List of **encoded** event IDs for information-only-events.

storedCorrelationIds.description: List of correlation IDs for problem-opening-events.

EventStoreResult.description: Contains IDs of all custom events, created by an event push call.

start.description:
The start timestamp of the event, in UTC milliseconds. 

If not set, the current timestamp is used. 

You can report information-only events up to **30 days** into the past. 

You can report problem-opening events up to **60 minutes** into the past.

end.description:
The end timestamp of the event, in UTC milliseconds. 

If not set, the current time is used for information-only events. 

Not applicable to problem-opening events. Such an event stays open until it times out depending on the **timeoutMinutes** parameter.

timeoutMinutes.description:
The timeout for problem-opening events in minutes. Not applicable to information-only events. 

If not set, 15 minutes is used. The maximum allowed value is 120 minutes. 

You can refresh the event by sending the same payload again.

additionalProperties.description: The set of any properties related to the event, in the *"key" : "value"* format.

customProperties.description: The set of any properties related to the event, in the *"key" : "value"* format.

 The format is the full name of the day in upper case, for example `WEDNESDAY`.

dayOfMonth.description: The day of the month for monthly maintenance.

The time zone of the start and end time. Default time zone is UTC. 

 You can user either UTC offset `UTC+01:00` format or the IANA Time Zone Database format.

entities.description:
Defines Dynatrace entities to be included in scope, for example hosts, services, process groups. 

Allowed values are Dynatrace entity IDs.

matches.description: An object defining a matching rule for dynamic scope formation. An empty rule matches for all entities.

MaintenanceWindowScope.description:
An object defining the scope of your maintenance window. 

You can specify particular Dynatrace entities or matching rules for dynamic formation of the scope. 

 If no scope is specified, the maintenance applies to the entire environment. 

 To specify the scope at least one entity or matching rule must be specified.

type.description: The type of the Dynatrace entities (for example, hosts or services) you want to pick up by matching.

tags.description:
The tag you want to use for matching. 

You can use custom tags from the UI, AWS tags, Cloud Foundry tags, OpenShift/Kubernetes, and tags based on environment variables.

MonitoredEntityFilter.description: Filters monitored entities by their type/tags.

value.description:
The value of the tag. Not applicable to custom tags. 

If a tag does have a separate key and value (in the textual representation they are split by the colon ‘:’), this field is set with the actual value. Key-value pairs can occur for automatically imported tags and tags set by rules if extractors are used.

key.description:
The key of the tag. For custom tags, put the tag value here.

The key allows categorization of multiple tags. It is possible that there are multiple values for a single key which will all be represented as standalone tags. Therefore, the key does not have the semantic of a map key but is more like a key of a key-value tuple. In some cases, for example custom tags, the key represents the actual tag value and the value field is not set – those are called valueless tags.

context.description:
The origin of the tag, such as AWS or Cloud Foundry. For custom tags use the `CONTEXTLESS` value. 

The context is set for tags that are automatically imported by OneAgent (for example, from the AWS console or environment variables). It’s useful for determining the origin of tags when not manually defined, and it also helps to prevent clashes with other existing tags. If the tag is not automatically imported, `CONTEXTLESS` set.

displayName.description: The name of the custom device that will appear in the user interface.

group.description:
User defined group ID of entity. 

The group ID helps to keep a consistent picture of device-group relations. One of many cases where a proper group is important is service detection: you can define which custom devices should lead to the same service by defining the same group ID for them. 

If you set a group ID, it will be hashed into the Dynatrace entity ID of the custom device. In that case the custom device can only be part of one custom device group. 

If you don't set the group ID, Dynatrace will create it based on the ID or type of the custom device. Also, the group will not be hashed into the device ID which means the device may switch groups.

ipAddresses.description:
The list of IP addresses that belong to the custom device. 

These addresses are used to automatically discover the horizontal communication relationship between this component and all other observed components within Smartscape. Once a connection is discovered, it is automatically mapped and shown within Smartscape. 

If you send a value (including an empty value), the existing values will be overwritten. 

If you send `null` or omit this field, the existing values will be kept.

listenPorts.description:
The list of ports the custom devices listens to. 

These ports are used to discover the horizontal communication relationship between this component and all other observed components within Smartscape. 

Once a connection is discovered, it is automatically mapped and shown within Smartscape. 

If ports are specified, you should also add at least one IP address or a host name for the custom device. 

If you send a value, the existing values will be overwritten. 

If you send `null`, or an empty value, or omit this field, the existing values will be kept.

type.description:
The technology type definition of the custom device. 

It must be the same technology type of the metric you're reporting. 

If you send a value (including an empty value), the existing value will be overwritten. 

If you send `null` or omit this field, the existing value will be kept.

favicon.description: The icon to be displayed for your custom component within Smartscape. Provide the full URL of the icon file.

configUrl.description: The URL of a configuration web page for the custom device, such as a login page for a firewall or router.

additionalProperties.description: The list of key-value pair properties that will be shown beneath the infographics of your custom device.

properties.description: The list of key-value pair properties that will be shown beneath the infographics of your custom device.

tags.description: List of custom tags that you want to attach to your custom device.

series.description:
The list of metric values that are reported for the custom device. 

Dynatrace aggregates all the values you report for a custom device. 

If you send a value (including an empty value), it will be added to the set of existing values. 

If you send `null` or omit this field, the set of existing values won't change.

hostNames.description:
The list of host names related to the custom device. 

These names are used to automatically discover the horizontal communication relationship between this component and all other observed components within Smartscape. Once a connection is discovered, it is automatically mapped and shown within Smartscape. 

If you send a value, the existing values will be overwritten. 

If you send `null` or an empty value; or omit this field, the existing values will be kept.

dataPoints.description:
List of data points. 

Each data point is an array, containing the timestamp and the value. 

Timestamp is UTC milliseconds reported as a number, for example: `1520523365557`. 

Values can't be reported more than **2 hours** into the past! 

A custom metric must be registered **before** you can report a metric value. Therefore, the timestamp for reporting a value must be after the registration time of the metric.

additionalProperties.description:
Data points of a metric. 

A JSON object that maps the ID of the entity that delivered the data points and an array, which consists of arrays of the data point float values.

 May contain more than one entity ID per record (for example, a host and its network interface). In such cases, entity IDs are separated by commas.

 A datapoint contains a value and a timestamp, at which the value was recorded. 

 Dynatrace stores data in time slots. The **dataPoints** object shows the *starting* timestamp of the slot. If the **startTimestamp** or **endTimestamp** of your query lies inside of the data time slot, this time slot is included into response. Due to the fact that the timestamp of the first data point lies outside of the specified timeframe, you will see *earlier* timestamp than the specified **startTimestamp** in the first data point of the response.

 There are three versions of data points: 
 * Numeric datapoint: Contains a numeric value. 
 * Enum datapoint: Contains an enum value, currently only for availability timeseries. 
 * Prediction datapoint: Similar to the numeric datapoint, but it contains a confidence interval, within which the future values are expected to be.

items.description:
Data points of a metric. 

A JSON object that maps the ID of the entity that delivered the data points and an array, which consists of arrays of the data point float values.

 May contain more than one entity ID per record (for example, a host and its network interface). In such cases, entity IDs are separated by commas.

 A datapoint contains a value and a timestamp, at which the value was recorded. 

 Dynatrace stores data in time slots. The **dataPoints** object shows the *starting* timestamp of the slot. If the **startTimestamp** or **endTimestamp** of your query lies inside of the data time slot, this time slot is included into response. Due to the fact that the timestamp of the first data point lies outside of the specified timeframe, you will see *earlier* timestamp than the specified **startTimestamp** in the first data point of the response.

 There are three versions of data points: 
 * Numeric datapoint: Contains a numeric value. 
 * Enum datapoint: Contains an enum value, currently only for availability timeseries. 
 * Prediction datapoint: Similar to the numeric datapoint, but it contains a confidence interval, within which the future values are expected to be.

Data points of a metric. 

A JSON object that maps the ID of the entity that delivered the data points and an array, which consists of arrays of the data point float values.

 May contain more than one entity ID per record (for example, a host and its network interface). In such cases, entity IDs are separated by commas.

 A datapoint contains a value and a timestamp, at which the value was recorded. 

 Dynatrace stores data in time slots. The **dataPoints** object shows the *starting* timestamp of the slot. If the **startTimestamp** or **endTimestamp** of your query lies inside of the data time slot, this time slot is included into response. Due to the fact that the timestamp of the first data point lies outside of the specified timeframe, you will see *earlier* timestamp than the specified **startTimestamp** in the first data point of the response.

 There are three versions of data points: 
 * Numeric datapoint: Contains a numeric value. 
 * Enum datapoint: Contains an enum value, currently only for availability timeseries. 
 * Prediction datapoint: Similar to the numeric datapoint, but it contains a confidence interval, within which the future values are expected to be.

If the **startTimestamp** or **endTimestamp** of your query lies inside of the data time slot, this time slot is included into response. displayName.description: The name of the metric in the user interface.

dimensions.description: The fine metric division, for example process group and process ID for some process-related metric.

aggregationTypes.description: The list of allowed aggregations for this metric.

filter.description: The feature, where the metric originates.

detailedSource.description: The feature, where the metric originates.

pluginId.description: The ID of the plugin, where the metric originates.

types.description: Technology type definition. Used to group metrics under a logical technology name.

TimeseriesDefinition.description: The configuration of a metric with all its parameters.

timeseriesId.description:
The case-sensitive ID of the metric, where you want to read data points. 

You can execute a GET timeseries request, to obtain the list of available metrics.

aggregationType.description:
The aggregation type for the resulting data points. 

If the requested metric doesn't support the specified aggregation, the request will result in an error.

startTimestamp.description: The start timestamp of the timeframe, in UTC milliseconds.

endTimestamp.description:
The start timestamp of the timeframe, in UTC milliseconds. 

If later than the current time, Dynatrace automatically uses current time instead. 

The timeframe must not exceed 6 months.

predict.description: The flag to predict future data points.

relativeTime.description: The relative timeframe, back from the current time.

queryMode.description:
Defines the type of result that the call should return. Valid result modes are:

`series`: returns all the data points of the metric in the specified timeframe.
 `total`: returns one scalar value for the specified timeframe. 

By default, the `series` mode is used.

entities.description:
Filters requested data points by entities which should deliver them. You can specify several entities at once. 

Allowed values are Dynatrace entity IDs. 

If the selected entity doesn't support the requested metric, the request will result in an error.

tags.description:
Filters requiested data points by entity which should deliver them. Only data from entities with the specified tag is delivered. 

You can specify several tags in the following format: `tags=tag1&tags=tag2`. The entity has to match *all* the specified tags. 

In case of key-value tags, such as imported AWS or CloudFoundry tags use following format: `[context]key:value`.

additionalProperties.description:
A filter is an object, containing map of filter keys and its values. Valid filter keys are:

 `processType`: Filters by process type. See Process types for allowed values.
`osType`: Filters by operating system. See OS types for allowed values.
`serviceType`: Filters by service type. See Service types for allowed values.
`technology`: Filters by technology type. See Technology types for allowed values.
`webServiceName`: Filters by web service name.
`webServiceNamespace`: Filters by the web service namespace.
`host`: Filters by entity ID of the host, for example HOST-007.

filters.description:
A filter is an object, containing map of filter keys and its values. Valid filter keys are:

 `processType`: Filters by process type. See Process types for allowed values.
`osType`: Filters by operating system. See OS types for allowed values.
`serviceType`: Filters by service type. See Service types for allowed values.
`technology`: Filters by technology type. See Technology types for allowed values.
`webServiceName`: Filters by web service name.
`webServiceNamespace`: Filters by the web service namespace.
`host`: Filters by entity ID of the host, for example HOST-007.

percentile.description:
Specifies which percentile of the selected response time metric should be delivered.

Only applicable to the `PERCENTILE` aggregation type. 

Valid values for percentile are between 1 and 99. 

Please keep in mind that percentile export is only possible for response-time based metrics such as application and service response times.

includeParentIds.description:
Specifies whether the results should exposes dimension mappings between parent entities and their children.

For instance: SERVICE-0000000000000001, SERVICE_METHOD-0000000000000001

considerMaintenanceWindowsForAvailabilit.description: Exclude (`true`) or include (`false`) data points from any [maintenance window](https://www.dynatrace.com/support/help/shortlink/maintenance-window), defined in your environment.

TimeseriesQueryMessage.description: Filtering parameters for a timeseries query.

displayName.description: The name of the metric that will appear in the user interface. It is limited to 256 characters.

unit.description: The unit the metric will use. If the parameter is not specified or the wrong value is specified, the `Count` value will be assigned.

dimensions.description:
The metric dimension key that will be used to report multiple dimensions. For example, a dimension key to report the metric for different network cards for the same firewall. 

The name of dimensions is only allowed to contain alphanumeric characters, dots ., hyphens -, and underscores _. 

The CUSTOM_DEVICE dimension is added to each new custom metric automatically.

types.description:
The definition of the technology type. Used to group metrics under a logical technology name in the UI. 

Metrics must be assigned a software technology type that is identical to the technology type of the custom device you are sending the metric to. 

For example, if you define your custom device using type `F5-Firewall` you must also register all related custom metrics as type `F5-Firewall`.

TimeseriesRegistrationMessage.description: The definition of a custom metric.

revoked.description: Revocation status of the token. Revoked tokens are disabled.

created.description: The creation time as a unix timestamp in milliseconds.

expires.description: The expiration time as a unix timestamp in milliseconds.

lastUse.description: The unix timestamp in milliseconds when the token was last used.

scopes.description: The list of permissions, assigned to the token.

The list of permissions assigned to the token. 

Apart from the new permissions, you need to submit the existing permissions you want to keep, too. Any existing permission, missing in the payload, is revoked.
